is in the Hauraki Gulf near
. It is 35 minutes by ferry from Auckland and is a popular destination for day trips and longer visits.

Waiheke Island is the third most populous island of New Zealand, with 8000 permanent residents, 2000 of whom commute to Auckland each work day. In summer the population swells dramatically, as the island is a popular destination for both overseas travellers and New Zealanders. The island is home to over 14 vineyards and its microclimate is well suited for winemaking. Olives are well established and some extremely nice olive oils are produced. Waiheke is administered by the Auckland Council.

passenger ferries (phone +64 9 367 9111) run from downtown Auckland to Matiatia on Waiheke Island, taking 40 minutes, hourly or more frequently between 6AM and 7:15PM and less frequently at night. Last departures from Waiheke are at 12:30AM M-Sa and 10:15PM Su. Ferries leave Auckland from Pier 2 ferry terminal, near the corner of Quay St and Albert St. Fullers buses and the Island Hopper hop-on-hop-off bus service depart at Matiatia. Taxis and hire cars are also available at Matiatia. Return fares are adult $36, child (5-15 years or high school ID) $18, seniors with a Supergold card are free - family passes are available. The
covers the Fullers ferries and Waiheke buses.
ferry stops at Orapiu on Waiheke at weekends on its return trips from Auckland to

. It departs Pier 4, downtown Auckland, Sa, Su and public holidays (except 25 Dec) at 8:45AM. Return trips depart Hannafords Wharf, Coromandel Harbour, at 4:30PM. Orapiu is on the south-eastern tip of the island, well away from the island's main residential region, and there is no public land transport. Auckland-Orapiu adult $25 one way, $41 return.

(phone +64 9 300 5900) operate a passenger/vehicle ferry service from Half Moon Bay to Kennedy Point on Waiheke, taking 45 minutes. Transfers are available from Kennedy Point. Standard return fares are adult $36.50, child $20, senior/student $31, car $152 and there are different family passes. Check their website for "hot deals" - sometimes two people with a car only have to pay for the car. Cheaper fares are also available with 10-trip tickets or with day return passes.
makes charter helicopter flights to Waiheke.

value: Bus services run around the main populated areas between Matiatia Wharf and Onetangi and Rocky Bay. They do not cover Kennedy Point, Orapiu or Stony Batter. All-day passes are available (but not before 9AM on weekdays). There are multiple taxi and shuttle services.

Cars, scooters or bicycles can be hired near the Matiatia ferry terminal. Vehicular ferries operate from Half-Moon Bay in Auckland, to Kennedy Point on Waiheke. Bicycles can be taken on all passenger ferries.
is commonplace with locals and visitors. Destinations are limited and distances are relatively small, which increases the chances of a driver stopping for hitchers.

), (+64) 9 372 2970. Open year round Wednesdays, Saturdays, Sundays, and Mondays if they are public holidays, noon–4PM.  Visit the woolshed museum and a 1930s restored cottage. There is also a photographic gallery and a textile display area. Admission is by donation.

content=9:30AM-3:30PM. World War II gun emplacements and tunnels. Located at the eastern end of the island. There is a 1.2 km (20 minute) walk from the carpark. Tunnel entry $5 per person, $15 per family; double those prices for a guided tour.

, a one hour 30 minute bus tour and commentary, twice a day in conjunction with ferry trips from Auckland. The tours start on arrival of the 10AM and noon sailings from Auckland. Bookings are essential. Fares include return ferry trip, the bus tour and an all-day bus pass for the regular bus services. Adult $42, child $21, senior $40, under 5s free.

), tastings at 3 vineyards and a light lunch. Ferry leaves Auckland at 11AM. Days vary with time of year. Waiheke Island produces some of New Zealand’s finest red wines which thrive in the hot, dry summers and stony soils. The vineyards are not large and wines are produced in limited quantities. Fare include return ferry trip, the tour and an all-day bus pass for the regular bus services. Adult $85.

content=Artworks, 2 Korora Road, Oneroa, 09 372 5573. Open 6 days; Tu by appointment only. 90-minute live performance at 1:30PM except Tu & F. Collection of accordions, pianos, organs and the like. Learn their history and the period they were made for.

The northern side of Waiheke is known for its relatively uncrowded white sand beaches, while the southern side beaches are quite tidal and swimming is dependent on the tides.

value: - The main beach, located along the northern side of the town of Oneroa.
- A small secluded beach at the east end of Oneroa Beach, separated by a protruding cliff wall.

- Similar in shape to Oneroa Beach (complete with protruding cliff wall on the east end that separates a small private beach in Boatshed Bay), it gets its name from the mature phoenix palms at the east end.
- A small clothes-optional beach at the west end of Palm Beach.
- The south-facing counterpart of Oneroa Beach, lining Blackpool and popular for kayaking and windsurfing.

- A zoned-in beach on the southern side of Surfdale, separated from Blackpool Beach by a small, protruding peninsula, which has a scenic unsealed route called The Esplanade linking the beaches. Popular for kitesurfing.
- A 1.9 km long, north-facing beach lining Onetangi. For many years it has been the site of the Onetangi Beach Races. Its western (and often inaccessible end at high tide) is clothes-optional.

- Considered by many Waihekeans as the island's most perfect beach and, with nearby Garden Cove, a romantic place for picnicking. The beach is accessible only by boat or kayak, as its land access was blocked off by a private landowner.

, Miami Ave, Surfdale. Nice thin crust pizza place with great outdoor seating area. BYO. Food is generally on time. Reasonably priced; pizzas $16 - $19. BYO but wine is also available.
, Oneroa Arts complex. Basic Indian, eat-in or takeaway.

, Miami Ave, Surfdale. Irish styled pub with reasonably priced beers including of course Guinness on tap. Nice food as well - particularly the Guinness Pie. Outside seating and pool table. Good place to watch the rugby or listen to live music on the weekends.
